Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2008 05:57AM kimbly wrote: I can totally feel and see mine as well.  I agree about the alien thing.. lol I have my last herceptin infusion Jan 2 and cannot wait for it to be out either! I could get it out in Dec with my exchange surgery but am not so sure I want the IV infusion method after months of using a port....
Posts.Title: Port question: Catheter from neck to port GointoCarolina bluedasher

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2009 01:51PM kimbly wrote: I had chose unilateral left side only mx with recon.   At the time I did not even consider a bilateral, I started thinking about it a few months after surgery and chemo were complete.  In fact I posted here when I started second guessing myself.  I did have a talk with both my onc. and my breast surgeon who both agreed no medical reason for me to make that decision AND not to make that decision right now.  I had MRI at the time of diagnosis(11/07) that lit my left breast up like a christmas tree but showed nothing on the right side, I had a mammo in July/08 that was also normal.  I have decided that I will go on to my next scheduled mammo and see how I feel, if i am experiencing excess worry etc I think I may choose to do the other side.  I am going to ask about the mammos and dense breasts though.
Posts.Title: Uni- or Bi-? robinjs19 robinjs19

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2008 07:16AM kimbly wrote: I do not think there is one person that wasn't scared to death of Chemo when they first heard the word.  I too had to have Xanax just to be able to calm down enough to think logically and make good decisions.  I was not given a choice of whether or not to have chemo.  I also had a doctor who had recently returned from the San Diego conference and she was so adamant that the Taxotere, carboplatin and Herceptin was my best choice.   It wasn't any fun but it is doable definately and way better than the alternative.  I am nearing the end of my herceptin infusions now as well ( started chemo last december.... year of herceptin and tamox for 5 yrs ) If you have to do it you can ..we are all much stronger than we give ourselves credit for I think.
Posts.Title: Chemo is scaring me so badly. Please help me. Mocity nanclee

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2009 07:47AM kimbly wrote: I was diagnosed with bc not to long after my 46th birthday.  There are no cancers on my mom's side of the family at all.  My dad is not my biological father he adopted me when he married my mother at age 3.  I have no idea of my paternal side of the family's health and if there are cancers there, since I have a daughter I opted to have the test done.  I  came back negative, I originally refused the test but then for the sake of my daughter and sisters I decided to test.  My insurance has still not paid but will pay or the test would not have been done... having that unknown and being on the age cusp was what prompted me to have the test...
Posts.Title: is there family history? vivo leaf

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2009 08:46PM kimbly wrote: What a beautiful little girl (granddaughter) you have.  Very unfair that this is happening to her.  I have never heard of a 10 year old having this diagnosis!  Please know that I too am praying for Hannah and for you as her family.
Posts.Title: HELP! 10 year old with bc cjsocal Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2008 01:44PM kimbly wrote: I was also called in for microcalcifications or so I thought.  They ended seeing a blurry spot as well that turned out to be IDC.  I had a screening mammo then the diagnositic a week later after my call back and then 3 days later a core biopsy.  Cancer.... 6x chemo treatments with Herceptin for a year. I had the  micros checked again in Jan and had a biopsy on that as well and also cancer so had to have a mastectomy instead of the lumpectomy.  All is well now .. I am almost a year up my diagnosis date and feeling great.. So good luck and your friend is right..my bil said the same thing.. it is what it is... I also had Xanax
Posts.Title: Please help, just joined LB2008 Dukemom2

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 07:45AM kimbly wrote: Lots of April surgery ladies wow... I was wondering though how many have already had chemo vs those who will have it after.  I had two biopsies at diagnosis and then chemo and now going for the lb mastectomy with recon April 30.  I will have radiation if I have positive nodes which will be determined at surgery.
Posts.Title: Anyone having surgery in April?? ottawagirl wahine

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2008 07:56AM kimbly wrote: Laughed alot at all these " why I hate being bald" comments.  I am no longer bald but rather have been compared to GI Jane.  I also remembered that I too have to renew my drivers license in August. Do I want to be sporting this short doo for the next 4 years in that photo?? I don't think so, *Sigh* will have to wear the wig.  I still wear my wig out in public just because I don't want to hear others cancers stories, or be the one people look at and think oh she has cancer. Of course they may just think i have short hair by choice...  It is true our hair as women is part of our identity and how dare it fall out so quickly and take for freakin' ever to grow back!!!  This just not right.   I did find out that my head is smaller than I thought ( all that hair I had made me think I had a bigger head as hats never fit me right)  AND that I look like my Uncle who is balding and shaves his head.  A compliment in a way cuz he is a good looking man.. but then do I want to look like a man??? um no... I think we need a thread where we all post pics of our hair growing back progression or just join the one titled hair hair hair.  I need to take a pic today, my last one is from june 24 and I have quite a bit more hair now although short.
Posts.Title: What I hate MOST about being bald! HeatherBLocklear dhettish

Posts.Content: May 4, 2008 06:11PM kimbly wrote: Hello all my April surgery friends, hope everyone is doing well!  Pretty Spring day today in Michigan and I actually left the house today.  I hate that my husband has to drive me everywhere but just for now is what I keep telling myself.  I see my plastic surgeon tomorrow and I hope that at least one of these annoying drains is removed.  I am emptying them okay but they are so annoying just dangling around under my clothes.  I have them pinned but still annoying.  I have not had to take one pain med today not even tylenol. I probably should have but not much pain so kept forgetting.  I will take half a vicodan to help with the discomfort while sleeping.  This expander feels so weird, and the  numbness is odd too.  I hope I get over how odd this feels soon.  So many dr's appt's this week... both surgeons and my onc. and my herceptin only drip!
Posts.Title: Anyone having surgery in April?? ottawagirl wahine

Posts.Content: May 8, 2008 04:09PM kimbly wrote: I am a week and a day out now and doing better every day.  I did have my drains out on Monday.  One of them was still draining somewhat but my ps pulled it anyway.  It has been fine.  I just keep it covered with some guaze and tape for now.  I don't like the feeling of the wound on my clothing.  I also keep my mast./recon scar covered for the same reason although I was told I didn't have to.  I have not bought a sports bra yet although I did see a Hanes one at Target today that I almost bought but I have to ask my dr because his remark to my question about bras was not yet as I want that expander to stay where I put it and of course I am very lopsided at the moment.  Been wearing tanks and camisoles with a zip or button up shirt and working out fine.  I did the same when I went out Sarah when i still had the drains.  It felt so good to get out. I was going stir crazy!  I had an appt with my onc. yesterday, my herceptin drip today and a appt with my breast surgeon tomorrow.  I am  tired this evening.  How soon after surgery can you expect to get arm movement back. I think I am doing pretty well moving sideways and in front/back etc.. its the above my shoulder that is rough.  I am doing the exercises but not as often as I should perhaps.  I also may be being a tad impatient.  LOL   (who me impatient never!  LOL)   What movies did you see??   Well wishes to all !!!!!
Posts.Title: Anyone having surgery in April?? ottawagirl wahine

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2008 01:38PM - edited Oct 5, 2008 01:39PM by kimbly  Yes I am ... I take Effexor daily and Xanax to help me sleep (.5 mg) It really has helped.  At first I had to take the Xanax during the day as well.  Now not so bad... I really like the Effexor it seems to work well with me.  I was on it during chemo ..w ent off for a bit but am back on now.
Posts.Title: Anyone out there taking anti-anxiety meds? Wink PugMum

Posts.Content: May 9, 2008 05:27AM kimbly wrote: Better to be safe then sorry. Call your doctor and get it checked out.

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2008 10:26AM kimbly wrote: Just found out my surgery date is April 30! SO lb mast. with imm. recon. for me!

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2008 12:46PM kimbly wrote: My plastic surgeon does a 'purse string cinch" rather than a cut straight across.  The skin being gathered up in the middle to later be a nipple. Anyone else heard of this?
Posts.Title: Anyone having surgery in April?? ottawagirl wahine

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2008 05:52PM kimbly wrote: My breast surgeon (expert in her field and best bedside manner ever) and the ps that I chose have worked together numerous times.  I went to this ps on her recomendation or her PA's at least.  He seemed so patient and very meticulous.  The nurse's in the office described him as a perfectionist and I could sense this just meeting him one time.  I have total trust in my dr's and this is very important as you all know.  I am lucky in that the cancer center and hosp are only 7 minutes from my house.  I am forever thankful that having had to deal with bc at least I feel into a good group of dr's.  Being in a selfish fog is so normal of course and I too am normally such a calm person.  I have my moments but am generally pretty well balanced and calm.  I am still calm ( 3 days to go) and hope that tuesday night I am not up all night worrying!!!! I am more worried about how I will be after the surgery rather than during. I just want to be able to be up and around and not out of commission completely for too long.  After 4 months of chemo and that down time I am sick of feeling sick LOL I will be thinking of you sally1965
Posts.Title: Anyone having surgery in April?? ottawagirl wahine

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2008 06:58AM kimbly wrote: Best wishes to all the April girls!!  I met with my surgeon last friday and she said possible surgery within the month so I may be an April girl as well.  I will post when I know for sure.  I only just had my last chemo march 27 so they will wait for both my blood counts to be good and to coordinate the two surgeons schedules ( immediate reconstruction planned) This will be lb only.... i just cannot wait to move on!!!!
Posts.Title: Anyone having surgery in April?? ottawagirl wahine

Posts.Content: May 2, 2008 10:06AM kimbly wrote: My surgery went well.  I am just a tad sore with the help of my friend vicodan. I have two drains that hopefully will go down to one at least by Monday.  It all seems so sureal to be honest.  Good news is that 3 nodes were taken and no cancer was found .. also no traces of the tumor in the breast either. I had titanium markers where it was and it was gone!! I knew the chemo had worked but when you hear that it just is so nice.  Sally1965 hope all went well for you yesterday!!! Take care everyone and thank you so much for all the well wishes!!
Posts.Title: Anyone having surgery in April?? ottawagirl wahine

Posts.Content: May 9, 2008 05:25AM kimbly wrote: My heart goes out to you Ms.Virgo. You are so young to have to go through this yet again.  I apologize I have no great advice, just know we are all here for you if you need us.  God Bless.
Posts.Title: Here I Go Again? msvirgo828 redheadace1

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2008 02:12PM - edited Jun 9, 2008 02:12PM by kimbly You know you can think all you want that it's "only hair" but for women it sort of defines us don't you think so when you lose it you lose part of who you are.  I know that does sound so ridiculous but it is so true.  I have had my hair varying lengths my whole life and was blessed with thick dark hair that had alot of body.  At the time of my diagnosis my hair was exactly how I wanted it, length, style everything. I was so upset when I heard I would lose it.  The first thing I said to anyone who would listen was " I wish I didn't have to lose my hair".  I did cut it to just below my chin a few weeks before chemo started.  It started falling out in hunks about 2.5 weeks after my first treatment. I had to shave it as it was getting everywhere.  I had my husband do it and not right to the scalp but maybe number 2's or 3's I think.  I never did lose that stubble.  Today 2 months post chemo I have peach fuzz all over the top of my head in places that were almost completely bald and the back well it is completely covered although short.  What is up with it growing mullet-like though I hate that. Bad thing for me is my stylist goes on maternity leave mid-July, right about the time I might need her to shape my very short hair.   I did buy a wig and wear it quite often, now with the extreme heat though I wear it less at least close to home.  The picture of me is with my wig on by the way.
Posts.Title: Mourning for my hair Sable MsKarin

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2008 06:07PM kimbly wrote: I had Taxotere, Carboplatin and Herceptin and did not completely lose my hair.  I had that male pattern baldness thing going on too.  Now my hair is coming in quickly although not as quickly as i would like.  I wear my wig less and a cap more.  At least I have a normal hairline in front now whereas a few weeks ago I had a receding hairline.  My last  chemo was end of march ... took about 6 weeks for it to grow and now it won't stop. I am back to shaving the legs everyday. Hair on my arms (which used to be quite hairy) is coming back and my eyebrows are thick again ( never lost them completely but they thinned) same goes for the eyelashes. I had hardly any bottom lashes for about 3 weeks and now they are coming back and are fine.  I just learned to be a master with the eyeliner and no one really noticed.  I too am always touching my head or looking in the mirror, back to front AND sides looking for new growh.  I just am so impatient!!!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2009 08:31AM kimbly wrote: My wig was great too and nice and warm during the winter months when I was bald!  Losing the hair is very traumatic but it is fine... and as you grow it out marks how each day you are further and further from chemo!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 05:42PM kimbly wrote: I am 47 and my hair came back grey and brown mixed.  I started coloring as soon as I had hair.. in fact the first color colored my scalp LOL.  I did use temporary Natural Instincts lasts about 28 shampoos and is pretty gentle on your hair.  I am now almost ... (March 27) a year out of treatment and my hair is just about ear lobe length.  I have had 3 haircuts and will be due for another probably in about 3 weeks.  I feel too young to leave my hair grey plus my grey is so colourless.  I know another bc survivor who is 51 and her hair came in curly , curly (mine has a wave but not curly) and it is the most beautiful shade of charcoal grey mixed with dark brown.  Very nice. I  think she wants to colour but for now I think it looks great!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2009 09:28PM kimbly wrote: I had haircut #4 today.  Finally my hair is over my ears! I had her just bring the back up a bit and clean up the sides somewhat.  She still has not had to cut my bangs.  I have to say that finally I have normal length bangs and I am thinking 2 more months and perhaps they will be long enough to trim as well.  I am particularily happy with the cut I got today.. feels more like a style without that mullet look in back.  Spring... I am with you btw COME ON  BANGS!!!!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2009 04:09PM kimbly wrote: Omg i love, love, love your extensions!!!! I am almost a year out from my last chemo and my hair is 3 inches or so long.  It is starting to grow much wish faster now thankfully!!.  How come our bangs don't grow btw...lol!!!!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 03:49PM kimbly wrote: I like that masquerading comment... LOL I was constantly getting compliments with my hair that short. I probably didnt need to explain but I usually did.  Now my hair is longer and crazy, I have gone about 8 weeks now without a trim but am getting one on Monday. I asked my onc about the thinning hair and she said most women say their hair grows in thicker.  not me... ugh oh w ell.. i had really thick hair before so no big deal if it is a bit thinner.  I also heard that it takes 18 months or so for it to really fill in.  I am at the 11 month mark right now.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 05:09PM kimbly wrote: The thinning hair is a concern but not that huge of a deal.  I think it will fill in.  I also have not had my hair this short in forever and all the natural layers well never had that I don't think.  I mean I have to remember that this is hair starting from nothing.  Others don't notice but I do... Oh and colouring helps give your hair some fullness as well.  I would love to put in hair extensions or a weave but big bucks that I just dont have.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2008 04:35PM kimbly wrote: WOW you do have alot of hair at 5 months out.  I am 7 months out and I swear I do not have as much as you.  The length varies all over my head, the front taking the longest to grow in.  It is very wavy, when wet I can say it is about 2 inches long on average.  I want to get a trim in a few weeks time. Just to shape it up a bit.  I have learned to use styling products to control it though as it will stick straight up at the crown if I don't.  I have been told my hair looks nice and that I look chic by people that don't know the history behind it.  That makes me feel good.

I am hmmm lets see.. 16 months PCF, and just had my first actual styling haircut last week. I had had 5 previous just trims to shape it cuts.  It took forever to grow the bangs.  This cut was the first time she touched them with the scissors at all.   Ladies it is a long process growing hair back, the key is have fun with it.  It makes you feel so much better to use color and to trim .. just makes you feel less and less like a cancer patient kwim?!!! Everyone looks great ....

This was one of those hankerchief type things. It had peace signs and stuff like that all over it.   Anyhow they let me keep it on under the surgery cap and I woke up and both were still on!  I too was paranoid about waking up with a bare head....

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2008 08:39PM kimbly wrote: I thought I posted a picture to this thread of my hair progress.. apparently I did not.... LOL let me see if I can now.

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2008 12:24PM kimbly wrote: Yes my hair is growing in faster and fuller in the back then on top.  The top has finally filled in but not as much as the back.  I have two spots one on either side of my head that are the most sparse.  It is aggravating to say the least. Deb, I feel kind of low like that too and am not going through rads. I wish the hair would grow in as fast as it fell out!!!  UGH. I think that is  a huge part of us feeling back to ourselves.   Lorena, cute what your son said.. very.  I have asked my daughter who is 13 many times about going without a hat.  She said mom no one will make fun.  Well I know that but I don't want all those cancer comments coming to me etc.. just like the one made to you.  I just want to go into a store and have short hair, not post chemo hair.  I cannot wait to be able to get my first styled cut, of course that is probably months away.  My hair stylist is going on maternity leave the end of this month and not returning to October.  She said by then you will have hair for me to cut!  OCTOBER??? seems like freakin forever.  Her mom died of breast cancer 16 or so years ago. (IBC)   I was wondering if anyone has shaved their head after it started growing in.  Not short but just enough to get rid of those straggly hairs that seem to be longer than the others.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2008 10:10AM kimbly wrote: Otter I think your hair looks great as well!!! It does take forever and ever..I am beginning to have dreams of having longer hair and waking very disappointed that it is not true!  I am 26 weeks post-chemo and yes I have a full head of hair but it is crazy hair. Different colors if i don't color(yes I have used temp colors several times now) and wavy as all get out.  I had lots of body in my hair to begin with so this is not really a surprise.  I belong to a support group locall that is for younger women with cancer (under 50) and there are women who are about a year out and I am told that their hair came in very curly but grew out and then with each hair cut was back to what they had before.  I cannot wait to get an actual style back in my hair.  I too get compliments on my hair and reply pretty much in the same way.. thank you but not my choice really.  Too bad there isnt some way to 'fertilize' our heads that is safe and really works! LOL

My hair is way thinner than it was prechemo.  It is growing (about 3 inches long now) in length and finally much more quickly now that the Herceptin is done.  I am on tamox right now but recently had an oomph and I know my onc wants me to switch to Arimidex.  What i hate is how thin it is on my part side and at the crown of my head.  I will be so distressed if it stays like this !!!!  Everyone who posted pics of hair progress .. hair looks great... and funny how so many have tight curls, wonder why.  My hair came in wavy but not curly.  I use a flat iron to clean it up a bit.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2008 10:34AM kimbly wrote: Waiting for the hair to grow back is the most frustrating thing ever don't you think.  I mean I finished chemo end of March and although my head is now mostly covered it is oh so very short still.  Longer in back and stubbly on top (which I am happy about believe me because I had some really bald spots for awhile)  I have coloured with a temporary colour already and that has helped me feel better, having so much white and colourless hair was so wierd to me.  I am naturally dark ( well *cough* with help now with all that peppery gray at my old age of 46, LOL ) I had surgery end of April and my  hair growth then stalled for a few weeks.  I just want it long enough to go without my wig in public.  I do wear a baseball cap out for exercising and yardwork etc but that is about that.  I am way too vain I guess. My hair always grew fast pre cancer/chemo so it would be nice if that is still true!  I have bought a magazine with short hairstyles in it and am planning my step by step cuts to where I want to get back to.. Suz It looks as if you you have more hair than I do and our chemo seems to be around the same time ( I started Dec 15 and ended March 28, although I had did Taxol, Carbo and herceptin).  As far as eyebrows and lashes.. mine also did not thin out until after chemo was done.  My eyebrows filled in again very quickly but my lashes are taking their time.  I still have some but they thinned so much it's hard to get mascara to look normal.  I have purchased sephora brand false eyelashes but haven't used them yet. Don't really intend to unless for a special occasion.   I am going to go look for athat hair thread now... I also inspect my head every day for growing progress...

I have not had my bangs trimmed at all yet as the front is taking the longest to come in.  UGH i too want my old hair back!!!

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2009 04:50PM kimbly wrote: I like the description of the new hair coming in with "little points" that is so right on! I have had 2 haircuts, the only part of my hair that has not been cut is my front/bangs as they are growing the slowest.  They still have that point look.  I figure by march I will have 'real' bangs.. geez.  I do take biotin the supplement not sure if it helps or not.  My last chemo was march 27/07 and I have that trendy pixie cut look now.

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2008 05:34PM kimbly wrote: I had my first at 35 and have no history of bc in my family that I know of ( adoptive dad).  The baseline was fine and so was the one after that done at age 41.  The cancer was found after 4 yrs of skipping... so i would get it now.
Posts.Title: when should i have my first mamogram? myhueandcry jezza

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 03:08AM kimbly wrote: Congrats on your 5 yrs!  So good to hear that you are doing well.  I am looking forward to being one to post that I am celebrating 5 yrs !  I have one more, yes one more chemo to go and then surgery and I am so excited.  I am 4 days post last chemo treatment and cannot repeat enough how excited I am about this.  I made it ... I made it .. through the thing that i thought I never would!!  So ladies that are just starting chemo, or in the same stage as me or just about to have surgery or post surgery... go go go... we can beat this.
Posts.Title: I was where you are - 5 years ago Sachi pconn03

Posts.Content: May 18, 2008 10:28AM kimbly wrote: I have been taking Effexor xr for a few months now and it does work well. I didn't really think I was depressed but instead described my symptoms as racing thoughts and not being able to sleep. The effexor helped alot.  It does take a few weeks to work.  I just started on the tamoxifen so perhaps the reason I am not experiencing hot flashes or night sweats is because I am already on effexor?  Good luck with all of this!!!!
Posts.Title: Anyone Had Good Results with Effexor? bluewillow Caya

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 02:57PM - edited Oct 29, 2009 02:58PM by kimbly I am on Arimidex still for 4 more years, chemo was complete March of 08.  I got my regular flu shot a few weeks ago and asked my gp about the h1n1 and she said they hadn't gotten it in yet.  I asked again yesterday when I was in with my daughter for her flu shot and they aren't getting any vaccine at all!  She recommended that we go to local health department.  I keep waivering on whether to get it or not.... there have been cases of it at my daughter's high school and at the college my son is attending.  I plan on asking my oncologist about it when I see her next which is a few weeks.

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2009 07:44PM kimbly wrote: I have 3 cats and they were my constant companions through chemo as well.  My kids and husband changed the litter box for me the week right after chemo. I actually did it the rest of the time wearing a mask and gloves.  LOL  We also had to dog sit a few times while I was going through chemo and this was so nice. That dog did not leave my side.  She is the reason we have the dog we do now!  We got an australian shepherd oct 31 and he is my constand companion now.  I couldnt imagine if i had to go through chemo again not being able to have him with me.
Posts.Title: Chemo and dogs wiz2 kimbly

Posts.Content: May 22, 2008 10:25PM kimbly wrote: I had surgery 4/30, my drains came out 5 days later.  I had a unilateral mastectomy.  My drains were the bulb ones and were long enough to come out the bottom of any shirt I wore.  I pinned them up and hid them under a sweat jacket or loose shirt though.  They exit from just to the side of under your arm. Drains are more annoying than anything really.

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2009 05:34PM kimbly wrote: mine came in wavy but not curly.  It has straightened out with more growth and a few haircuts.  I did have quite a bit of body before.  It does take forever though. I am 10 months out and it's just now covering  my ears.
Posts.Title: does everyone get curly hair after chemo? cc01 lago

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2009 02:59PM kimbly wrote: I had my port out Feb 4 in outpatient surgery but chose not to be asleep and instead just did the numbing thing. Have to say the needle to numb hurt alot but only for maybe 10 seconds.  I was glad I did it this way because I too "danced my way out" afterwards!!.  I had my port put in Dec 5/2007 and out Feb 4/2009.  I finished my chemo march 28/2008 but then had chemo until end of December 2008.  I had such mixed feelings about having it out.  I wanted it out because it did tend to get in my way at times and well it showed when I wore scoopy necked shirts.  I wanted it in because I felt superstitious about having  out.  My onc and surgeon both said.. understood but IF EVER needed, and no reason to think this, again we can easily reinsert one.
Posts.Title: Port Removal sunshine787990 liz19

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2009 01:53PM kimbly wrote: Standard procedure.  I had a muga scan right before I started chemo and herceptin, and then again 3 months later etc until Herceptin was complete which was just at the end of December.  I would not worry too much. Good luck with the rest of your tx!
Posts.Title: Muga Scan test 1/2 way through Chemo? Scrappygrl Scrappygrl

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2008 02:47PM kimbly wrote: I had neoadjuvant TCH which was completed at the end of March.  The chemo did shrink my tumor away to almost nothing.  I ended up having a left side mastectomy as it was found later that I had microcalcifications in another quadrant.  I was so happy to have have the chemo out of the way.
Posts.Title: Anyone done neoadjavant chemo? mommy3abm Joyceska

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2008 04:35PM kimbly wrote: I had chemo first as well.  Purpose was to shrink the tumor because at first I had a choice as to whether have a lumpectomy or mastectomy.  I am glad I had it first because once I had the mastectomy I was done and could move on.  I recently joined a YSC group and there were several women who had children after chemo.  One for sure naturally.  Some said that their onc. suggested they freeze their eggs just in case chemo puts them into permanent menopause.  I did read though that the younger you are when you get chemo the better chance you will go back to 'normal;.
Posts.Title: Chemo first? Payne petelzmom

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2008 06:30PM kimbly wrote: Not sure about the flight as a matter of fact.  This is a cruise that they got as a freebie.  Last year they went on a European cruise and had a bad experience. Ship got damaged and they never left their first port. NOT a bad port to be at though .. as they were in Italy.  SO... I am not sure which cruise they chose as their freebie.  I have been on one cruise and it was not a good experience for me at all.  Everyone was seasick, my daughter who was 3 at the time got some wierd flu virus as well as my husband.  It was a nightmare.  I guess at this point I will wait and see if they can even transfer the cruise to us.  Alot of times they won't allow it at all anyway.  Thanks for your advice ladies
Posts.Title: Traveling after chemo kimbly lilith

Posts.Content: kimbly wrote: How does everyone feel about travel after having gone through chemo/surgery? Travel as in big travel, international.  My inlaws have a cruise they were to go on in August. My fil's leukemia has returned and he has started back on chemo.  They are trying to get us to take their place on this cruise.  I am not sure of details of the cruise yet and not sure that it is even transferrable.  Thing with me is I finished chemo 2 weeks ago, so end of March.  I will have surgery end of April, mastec with recon.  I do not want to travel far from home this year.  I was thinking maybe of a 5 day to Vegas or some weekends away in the summer with the kids. My husband thinks I am being nuts.  I just don't think he understands.  The one place I don't want to be is on a cruise ship, floating germs.  Perhaps I am paranoid but it seems like it would be too much.  Am I nuts??? Dx 11/21/2007, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Traveling after chemo kimbly lilith

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2009 07:51PM kimbly wrote: It is a shame that you are not getting all your info all at once, and that it's sort of coming in bits and pieces. I  had invasive ductal and DCIS myself and it did throw me into a tailspin when i  was told I had to have a mastectomy, that a lumpectomy wasnt even a choice. I  did not do a bilateral though as nothing showed in the other breast.  I would definitely get another opinion.  As far as the pain involved yes there is pain but it is manageable.
Posts.Title: Feel like I am being jerked around... Ang7 SJW1

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2008 04:29PM kimbly wrote: I took 2 tablets morning and night day before chemo, day of chemo and day after.  I think they were 8mg each.  This was 5 months ago and I threw out the bottle.  I can say that the last time I had to take those I celebrated.  I too am caffiene sensitive and the decadron put me through the roof.  I absolutely hated it.  Good that you got them to cut it.
